Apr 12

6 quotes from non-sales movies, and how they inspire salespeople

“Remember this day, men, for it will be yours for all time.”

With Leonidas’ blessings, we begin.

When you’re in sales, watching classics like Glengarry Glen Ross, Cadillac Man, Tin Men, or The Pursuit of Happyness is a rite of passage. If you don’t watch them, the internet will keep reminding.

And make no mistake about any of these movies. You can’t go wrong with Al Pacino, Will Smith, or Robin Williams.

Certainly not with Danny DeVito.

But movies in general have this ability to give us lines we never knew how we lived without. If “You talkin’ to me?” flashed in your head, we’re grinning too.

So we decided to dig into a random bunch of movies and find out if the lines in there resonate with a life in sales.

We start with The Six.

1.“Neo, sooner or later you’re going to realise just as I did that there’s a difference between knowing the path and walking the path.” [The Matrix]

Good ol’ Morpheus.

So many lines in The Matrix are motivational poster material. This one, well… in an ideal world, every Sales Manager would be telling this to every sales rep on their team.

When you’re training for sales, you’re put through the grind: doing mock calls, listening to call recordings of colleagues, running through case studies, and creating buyer personas. It’s important to tap into this input, but when you pick up that phone for your first live call, it helps to remember that people are unique — so are situations and challenges.

Also, a training tip could sound really simple, like greeting your contact when you end your call. But when you start making your calls, it takes practice to make this closing greeting (i) a natural part of your conversation, and (ii) sound upbeat when you say it to 50 leads through the day.

Walking the path.

How would Yoda probably describe it? A better teacher, there is never.

2. “My momma always said, ‘Life was like a box of chocolates. You never know what you’re gonna get.’ ” [Forrest Gump]

Trying to select an iconic line uttered by Tom Hanks is like making a choice in a chocolate factory. This line, though, seems to have an uncanny relevance to salespeople.

You pick up that phone every day and you send out all those mails, but every action boils down to a leap of faith.

How many leads are likely to open your latest email?

How many deals will you close this month?

Can you predict how your next call will go?

It’s this uncertainty that makes sales exciting.

Just imagine you kept clinching a deal with every lead this quarter (not that it’s likely, but still). Or imagine you got rejected by every lead for an entire week (a bit more likely, but here’s hoping it’s not on you).

Either way, you’d be bored stiff.

It’s important to be prepared for surprise; it’s vital to adapt to change.

3. “But it ain’t about how hard you hit. It’s about how hard you can get hit and keep moving forward.” [Rocky Balboa]

When he’s not using his fists or fancy guns, Stallone is busy doling out life advice. And he’s rarely off target.

If salespeople got a dollar every time they were rejected, they’d leave sales and start their own company. Sometimes the rejections last a week; sometimes they can ruin your quarter.

It’s easier to fret and dig a hole into the ground. It doesn’t wash away the pain.

It’s harder to step back and show yourself some tough love. It doesn’t wash away the pain either.

But it does put you on the road to a comeback.

Before your manager steps in and points out where you’re going wrong, do it yourself. Analysing call durations, scripts, opening lines, and cadence of communication are just the take-off points. You could also use the analytics from your CRM to help you make data-driven corrections.

How much you want to critique yourself depends on how badly you want to do better.

That which does not kill us, makes us stronger. Friedrich Nietzsche FTW.

4. “If you build it he will come.” [Field of Dreams]

In the movie, this line has a certain context — doing something drastic and believing it’ll work. From a sales perspective, you can interpret the line from a different stance, and you still won’t miss out on insight.

Converting a lead into a customer is a persistent journey. Salespeople don’t need to be reminded about that. So it helps when you don’t forget the operative word in that quote: build.

For sales folks, building is all about constructing a solid pipeline.

By making clear distinctions for hot, warm, and cold leads in your CRM, you build a well-oiled pipeline. This empowers you in a couple of ways:

  • You have better visibility on your leads.
  • You manage your time better by following the right leads.

It goes without saying, of course, that following up consistently is the underlying action behind all this effort.

Build the pipeline, and the deals will come.

5. “Louie, I think this is the beginning of a beautiful friendship.” [Casablanca]

One of the most memorable closing lines spoken on celluloid, it’s also a great sentiment to remember after you’ve closed a deal.

You’ve shadowed the lead, made the right moves, and won the deal. It’s tempting at this point to shake hands and move to the next deal.

But if you want to make a difference, this is when you do it.

Keep the conversation going by getting to know how the customer feels about the product. Pay attention to feature requests they may have; make it a point to follow up with updates on the availability of such features.

On the surface you’re communicating that you value this relationship. But you’re also presenting an image of your organisation, and the kind of deal your customer is getting into.

6. “You is smart, you is kind, you is important.” [The Help]

This goes beyond toddler-level advice.

Every day you’re meeting deadlines, hitting targets, and — facing your manager. The heat is on and it can often spill over. A promising deal may have fallen through, and your manager unloads on you. Sometimes, the tirade may even sound personal.

That’s when it’s crucial to remember this line.

Because at the end of the day, no one can motivate you like yourself. It’s important to remember that, like everything else, this too shall pass. And what remains is the fact that you matter. Not just to your team and to your organisation, but to your family, your friends, and to everyone else outside your office.

Because they need you in their lives, irrespective of whether you’re closing million-dollar deals or struggling to convert a bunch of leads.

If you’re wondering why there isn’t a single Star Wars quote in here, that’s because we already have a separate blog, analysing 19 quotes.

Back in this blog, the quotes are a mix of personal favourites and cult classics. We picked the classics from an audience poll conducted by The Hollywood Reporter.

Which brings us to the question we want to ask you. Which movie line best describes your life in sales? Join the discussion in the Comments!

(To Radhika, Aroop and Joshua Preetham — thank you for helping me put this blog together.)
